Part 1a: The Origin and Evolution of Plants: Lecture 1

In the Bryophytes, the major party of the life cycle is the haploid gametophyte. The small diploid sporophyte is always attached to the gametophyte body and is parasitic on it. There are three related groups:

Liverworts: Hepaticopsida
Hornworts: Anthocerotae
Mosses: Bryopsida

More detailed information

event.title: Club-moss and Fern Allies Life Cycle

data.event:
Part 1a: The Origin and Evolution of Plants: Lecture 1

Reproduction in all spore-formers is water-dependent since sperm must swim to the eggs. There are two major living groups of spore producers: club mosses, and ferns and their allies:

Club-mosses: Lycophyta
Ferns and their allies:
Horsetails (Sphenophyta) and Ferns (Pterophyta)

More detailed information

Part 1a: The Origin and Evolution of Plants: Lecture 1

Psilotum (the whisk fern) is a spore-producing vascular plant. The sporophyte produces haploid spores by meiosis protected by a desiccation-resistant coat of sporopollenin. This polymer is the most decay-resistant biological product known and coats all spores and pollen grains.

The haploid spores of Psilotum germinate and grow down underground. A tiny body forms, dependent entirely on fungi for its nutrition. Archegonia and antheridia differentiate and motile, flagellate sperm swim in a water film over the surface to fertilise the egg to which they are attracted chemically. Cross fertilisation can also occur where gametophytes are dense. The zygote develops into an embryo which then pushes up a shoot into the light, and the cycle completed.

Part 1a: The Origin and Evolution of Plants: Lecture 1

The seed plants began to dominate the earth 250 million years ago with the proliferation of the gymnosperms. On the sporophyte, a megaspore develops inside the ovule. The ovule is surrounded by extra layers of sporophyte tissue (the integuments), leaving only a very small pore (the micropyle) for the entry of sperms.

After fertilisation occurs, the whole thing becomes a seed and the sporophyte-derived integuments become a protective seed coat. This grows around the ovule and seals it in completely. The free-living gametophyte has disappeared. But now we have long lived, resistant seeds which can enter a deep state of dormancy for hundreds of years.

Part 1a: The Origin and Evolution of Plants: Lecture 1

Protection of the megaspore (egg) led to the evolution of seeds. Seed plants came to dominance when the world dried out in the Permian era about 250 mya. There are four groups of seed plants - Cycads, the maidenhair tree Ginkgo, the common conifers and the Angiosperms.

More detailed information
